I'm not sure how accurate he is, but here's a link to a blogger that thinks there is an emerging urlLink democratic majority. Sort of contradicts this morning's urlLink Brooks column in the Times. Though I find Brooks to be a one-dimensional columnist - beating the polarization horse to death - his piece today was interesting not because he revisited the polarization theme again, but because he brought up the Bayh-McCain proposal for voluntary national service as a way to bridge ideological gaps in our culture. Why not take it a step further and require either national service or military service. At least the rich would have to do national service provided there are no favors that can be granted ala Bush and his national guard "service". Would people really object to having to spend a year rebuilding cities, upgrading rural infrastructure and planting trees? And if they object, should we abandon the idea? Hardly. Remember JFK, "ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country". Sadly most of us do nothing, but we can and should step up. And since we can't entice anyone to serve except those without opportunity, perhaps it is time to require service. Maybe then we can reinstill a civic ethic in our citizenry.
